IMPORTANT: Potential COVID Exposure in Pleasantville

Good evening: It has come to the attention of the Valhalla Union Free School District that on Monday, Aug. 28, 2020, a priest from Holy Innocents Church in Pleasantville tested positive for COVID-19. Unfortunately, that priest recently distributed communion at a First Holy Communion Ceremony.

The Westchester County Department of Health is directing anyone who was present at the ceremony to self-quarantine for a period of two weeks. Since the priest’s COVID testing was on Aug. 28, 2020, the quarantine would go through and include Sept. 10, 2020. If any of our families were present at this ceremony, you should self-quarantine and contact the Westchester County Department of Health to alert them that you were present at the ceremony. This will allow for the contact tracing program to identify and assist anyone who may be affected. The contact tracing phone number for the Department of Health is 866-588-0195.

Click below for more information.

OWL RESCUE: At 7:30 a.m. on July 28, Valhalla Schools’ Director of Facilities Peter Kelly received a call from his maintenance foreman that an owl was tangled in the soccer net on the south side of Viking Stadium.

Mr. Kelly promptly called the Mount Pleasant Police Department, who dispatched the town’s animal control officer. Soon after, Jim Horton (in video), Mount Pleasant’s wildlife rescue contractor from Quality Pest and Wildlife Services, arrived on the scene.

Upon inspection, the adult owl had its head, feet and both wings completely intertwined in the net’s ropes. Over the course of 20 minutes, Mr. Kelly and Mr. Horton cut the net to free the owl.

“It was good to let the bird go,” said Mr. Kelly. “Being an avid outdoorsman, I do enjoy those things. In these types of situations, there comes a time when the animal understands you’re not there to hurt it. It was nice to do something like that.”

On Friday, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo announced that schools across the state will open for in-person classes in September. Valhalla Schools will be opening with a hybrid model. To best share our reopening plan and to answer questions from community members, we will be hosting one virtual meeting per school on Aug. 17 and 18.

Our local governments are asking Valhalla community members to complete the census form to ensue that Westchester County is accurately represented. Read more about the census below.

Please visit https://www.westchestergov.com/census2020 to ensure that you're counted.

"Data from the Census will be used for the next ten years for many things - including determining New York State’s representation in Congress as well as local districting. Census data is also used for the distribution of about $880 Billion of federal funds to local municipalities according to a December 2018 report from the George Washington Institute on Policy.
The Census Bureau estimates that every person that is not counted equals a loss of approximately $2,500 per year to local municipalities. This means that every 400 people who are not counted equates to a loss of about $1 Million in funding - each year.
We need to get everyone living in Westchester counted."

New York State Governor Andrew Cuomo’s Executive Order #206.26 has greatly altered the traditional ways that we prepare our budget vote.

As a young girl, Valhalla High School senior Jennifer Jacobs folded a sheet of paper into three sections. Playing a creative illustration game, she drew the head and shoulders of a person onto the top third. She then folded the paper so that her drawing was hidden and the blank, middle section of paper was showing. She gave the sheet to her father, who sketched the torso and arms there. He then hid his creation and passed it back to his daughter so that she could pencil in the legs and feet. When finished, they opened the paper to reveal a discombobulated creature and giggled at their final product.

Jennifer was one of 10 VHS seniors who participated in the Katonah Museum of Art’s “Young Artists 2020” exhibit. The 37th annual show, which was on display from Feb. 9 to March 1, highlighted the artwork of nearly 400 high school students from Westchester, Putnam, Dutchess and Fairfield counties.

“I was honored to be selected but kind of surprised,” she said. “I was inspired by my father to start drawing. We would doodle together. Art is so much fun and brings back so many memories.”
